citeinfo.title: transects_transects_20240409_142211 - Digital Shoreline Analysis System Version 6.0.141 Rates
Project title
citeinfo.othercit: This metadata record is a template for data created using the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Digital Shoreline Analysis System (DSAS) version 6.0 application. Basic process steps and attribute fields have been described but many required fields have been left blank for the DSAS user to enter their specifications. In particular, the coordinate system is not included, this information can be found in the summary report produced by DSAS. Therefore, this metadata file is not FGDC-compliant as is. The Digital Shoreline Analysis System (version 6) is a desktop application that loads GeoJSON files saved by a Geographic Information System. The DSAS software requires users to import a reference baseline and a set of shoreline positions. DSAS will then generate measurement transects and shoreline intersections which it will use to calculate rate-of-change statistics. In addition, DSAS provides uncertainties associated with rates of change. This metadata file accompanies a rates file of the same name ([name]_[timestamp]) that was created using the Digital Shoreline Analysis System version 6.0.

idinfo.useconst: These data were automatically generated using the DSAS version 6.0 software application and should only be used for purposes explicitly stated by the originating organization.

dataqual.logic: These data were generated using DSAS, an automated software program which does not perform checks for fidelity of the input features. Any testing on these data should be carried out by end-users to ensure fidelity of relationships.
dataqual.complete: This dataset contains transects with change rate information generated by the rate calculation tool in the DSAS version 6 application. Incomplete fields in the metadata record should be updated by the DSAS user.

procstep.procdesc: Transect features generated using DSAS version 6.0.141. Parameters Used: baseline layer=BigBay_baseline, baseline group field=FID, transect spacing=10, search distance=250, baseline placement=Off shore, smoothing distance=0, For additional details on these parameters, please see the DSAS help file distributed with the DSAS software, or visit the USGS DSAS page at: https://woodshole.er.usgs.gov/project-pages/DSAS/

Shoreline intersects and rate calculations performed. Parameters Used: transect file=transects_transects_20240409_142211, shoreline layer=BigBay_merged, shoreline date field=USDate, shoreline uncertainty field name=Total_UNCY, the default accuracy=10m, stats calculations=EPR,LRR,NSM,SCE,WLR, shoreline threshold=1, confidence interval=90.0%. Process Date=Âƒ20240409

enttyp.enttypd: Rate transects are generated by DSAS and are returned as a transect rate GeoJSON file.

attrdomv.udom: Unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number of the baseline segment. Used by DSAS to determine transect ordering alongshore if multiple baseline segments exist.
Assigned by DSAS based on ordering of transects along the baseline. Allows user to sort transect data sequentially alongshore from baseline start to baseline end.
Assigned by DSAS to indicate whether or not a DSAS-generated transect has been modified (0= auto-generated DSAS transect; 1= DSAS transect has been edited by the user).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Woods Hole Science Center

attr.attrdef: The TransectID relates directly to the original transect file identifier (OBJECTID).
The total number of shorelines intersected by the transect and used for change analysis.

A linear regression rate-of-change statistic was calculated by fitting a least-squares regression line to all shoreline points for a particular transect. The best-fit regression line is placed so that the sum of the squared residuals (determined by squaring the offset distance of each data point from the regression line and adding the squared residuals together) is minimized. The linear regression rate is the slope of the line. The rate is reported in meters per year with positive values indicating accretion and negative values indicating erosion.

The R-squared statistic, or coefficient of determination, is the percentage of variance in the data that is explained by a regression. It is a dimensionless index that ranges from 1.0 to 0.0 and measures how successfully the best-fit line accounts for variation in the data. The smaller the variability of the residual values around the regression line relative to the overall variability, the better the prediction (and closer the R-squared value is to 1.0).

The confidence interval (LCI) is calculated by multiplying the standard error of the slope by the two-tailed test statistic at the user-specified confidence percentage. This value is often reported in conjunction with the slope to describe the confidence of the reported rate. For example: LRR = 1.2 and LCI90 = 0.7 could be reported as a rate of 1.2 (+/-) 0.7 meters/year. These are positive decimal values in meters.

This quantity is the standard error of the regression, also known as the standard error of the estimate. To calculate it, the distance between each data point and the regression line is calculated. These distances are squared then summed. The sum is divided by the number of data point minus two. The square root is taken of the result. These are positive decimal values in meters.

The end point rate (EPR) is calculated by determining the distance between the oldest and youngest shoreline on a DSAS transect and dividing by the time elapsed between the two shoreline dates. Decimal values may be positive or negative, which is used to indicate landward (negative) or seaward (positive) shoreline movement. Reported in meters per year.

Describes the uncertainty of the reported end point rate in meters. The shoreline uncertainties for the two positions used in the end point calculation are each squared, then added together (summation of squares). The square root of the summation of squares is divided by the number of years between the two shorelines. This result is reported as the confidence of the end point rate calculation (EPRUNC).
Net shoreline movement (NSM) is the distance between the oldest and youngest shorelines at each transect.
The shoreline change envelope (SCE) value represents the greatest distance among all the shorelines that intersect a given transect. The value for SCE is always positive.

In a weighted linear regression (WLR), more reliable data are given greater emphasis or weight towards determining a best-fit line. In the computation of rate-of-change statistics for shorelines, greater emphasis is placed on data points for which the positional uncertainty is smaller.

The R-squared statistic, or coefficient of determination, is the percentage of variance in the WLR that is explained by a regression. It is a dimensionless index that ranges from 1.0 to 0.0 and measures how successfully the best-fit line accounts for variation in the data. The smaller the variability of the residual values around the regression line relative to the overall variability, the better the prediction (and closer the R-squared value is to 1.0).

The confidence interval (WCI) is calculated by multiplying the standard error of the slope by the two-tailed test statistic at the user-specified confidence percentage. This value is often reported in conjunction with the slope to describe the confidence of the reported rate. For example: WLR = 1.2 and WCI90 = 0.7 could be reported as a rate of 1.2 (+/-) 0.7 meters/year. These are positive decimal values in meters.

This quantity is the standard error of the regression, also known as the standard error of the estimate. To calculate it, the distance between each data point and the regression line is calculated. These distances are squared then summed. The sum is divided by the number of data point minus two. The square root is taken of the result. These are positive decimal values in meters.
The total cumulative distance (TCD) measures rate transect distance in meters alongshore from the start of the baseline segment with an ID=1 to the end of the last baseline segment.

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describe the attributes that are generated using the Digital Shoreline Analysis System version 6 software. In some cases, the attributes described in this metadata file may not exist in the dataset. It is up to the DSAS user to verify the attributes and ensure all values are populated with regard to their dataset.

digtinfo.formspec: GeoJSON is an open standard geospatial data interchange format that represents simple geographic features and their nonspatial attributes.
digtinfo.formcont: Based on JavaScript Object Notation (JSON), GeoJSON is a format for encoding a variety of geographic data structures. GeoJSON files can be converted to and from shapefiles in GIS software.

cntorgp.cntorg: The name of an organization associated with the dataset
cntorgp.cntper: The individual associated with the dataset

cntaddr.address: The address of the organization or individual
